title: What's the best writing prompt for a creative writer? - Quora

response.answer_text: What's the best writing prompt for a creative writer? The one that gets you writing. For every writer, the ‘prompt’ will be different. For one writer, it may be an anthology call. The theme might be something like women who’ve lost their children, and a large number of authors will immediately start writing their story because the theme speaks to them personally. Another, larger number of writers will try it out just so that they can submit a story and hopefully get published. That’s okay too. They’re writing. For another writer, the ‘prompt’ will be their writing habit. At 9am, every day, rain or shine, sick or well, they’ll be at their computer, writing. Every rare once in a while they might miss a day because it’s a holiday or they’re on a trip and the time zone change has messed with their groove. But they’ll probably still write sometime that day, even if it’s just to write out an answer on Quora. Yet another writer may be ‘prompted’ by a strong feeling, or by a view from a cliff, or by a news article that makes them think of a ‘what if’ scenario, or by an event in their lives, or because they have less than a buck in the bank and they need to write anything and get it published or the lights will go out in thirty days. What will get you to write? Only you can answer that.

What’s the best writing prompt for a creative writer? The one that drives your fingers to the keyboard or your hand to hold a pen, that makes your hands itch to pour words onto the screen or the page. The prompt that launches a rolling rush of words, ideas, dialogue, paragraphs…page after page until you can pause for a real or a mental breath. It might be the melody line in a song. A burst of color from sunlight on a passing bird’s wing. Your own reflection on the side of a car. The arc of a golfball. A photograph from 1927 of Djuna Barnes and Olaf Stapledon at a cafe table in Paris…or one of yourself eating an ice cream cone at age five. Or it might be a stanza of Wordsworth. Or Collins. Anything might be a prompt. Despite the advances of neuroscience, we don’t know exactly how or what or when our creativity sparks into action. I—and maybe you—have pulled off the road to capture a piece of deathless prose (or a less grandiose fragment of a few nearly illegible words). Perhaps better if you ask writers—and all are creative by definition—what doesn’t result in a cathartic moment when we fabricate something from absolutely nothing but our membership in the human race.
